title: Model-Based Control Design for a Composite Heater Using MATLAB/Simulink
overview: The goal of this project was to use the MATLAB/Simulink toolchain to perform system identification of a composite heater and design a controller using a model-based approach.
The project was conducted independently within the AGH Solar Boat Student Research Group as a learning-focused exercise in model-based design and embedded deployment workflows.
highlights: Refactored the old embedded software I originally wrote for the composite heater, splitting it into modular files and adding UART-based data logging.
Developed a MATLAB script to receive CSV-formatted data, visualize it with plots, and support system identification.
Conducted a step response experiment, filtered the data, and fitted a transfer function model to represent the plant.
Built a Simulink model replicating the system, integrating parts of the original C code using LCT (Legacy Code Tool), effectively creating a digital twin.
Designed a PID controller in Simulink, manually tuning each component (P, I, D) to understand their individual influence on performance.
Generated embedded C code from the Simulink model and verified build correctness for the target platform.
Final stage includes real-world tests and comparison between the plant model and actual hardware response.
Key technical challenge: fitting Simulink-generated code and legacy logic within the memory and performance limits of a small AVR microcontroller.
results: A validated plant model and simulation environment were created, including a digital twin with integrated legacy C code.
The project successfully demonstrated a complete model-based workflow: data acquisition, system identification, controller design, and code generation.
The outcome serves as a solid foundation for future closed-loop control experiments on more complex embedded systems.
